chapter.title: Hadoop for Developers
chapter.para: This section is a quick 'fact sheet' in a Q&A format.
Hadoop is an open source software stack that runs on a cluster of machines. Hadoop provides distributed storage and distributed processing for very large data sets.
chapter.bridgehead: Is Hadoop a fad or here to stay?
chapter.para: Sure, Hadoop and Big Data are all the rage now. But Hadoop does solve a real problem and it is a safe bet that it is here to stay.

Below is a graph of Hadoop job trends from Indeed.com. As you can see, demand for Hadoop skills has been up and up since 2009. So Hadoop is a good skill to have!
Hadoop Job Trends
chapter.bridgehead: What skills do I need to learn Hadoop?
chapter.para:
A hands-on developer or admin can learn Hadoop. The following list is a start - in no particular order
Hadoop is written in Java. So knowing Java helps
Hadoop runs on Linux, so you should know basic Linux command line navigation skills
Some Linux scripting skills will go a long way
chapter.bridgehead: What kind of technical roles are available in Hadoop?
chapter.para: The following should give you an idea of the kind of technical roles in Hadoop.

row.entry: develops MapReduce jobs, designs data warehouses
manages Hadoop cluster, designs data pipelines
Linux administration, Network Management, Experience in managing large cluster of machines
Data mining and figuring out hidden knowledge in data
Pig, Hive, SQL superman, familiarity with other BI tools

chapter.bridgehead: I am not a programmer, can I still use Hadoop?
chapter.para: Yes, you don't need to write Java Map Reduce code to extract data out of Hadoop. You can use Pig and Hive. Both Pig and Hive offer 'high level' Map Reduce. For example you can query Hadoop using SQL in Hive.
chapter.bridgehead: What kind of development tools are available for Hadoop?
chapter.para:
Hadoop development tools are still evolving. Here are a few:
Karmasphere IDE : tuned for developing for Hadoop
Eclipse and other Java IDEs : When writing Java code
Command line editor like VIM : No matter what editor you use, you will be editing a lot of files / scripts. So familiarity with CLI editors is essential.
